IMAGE-HIGH-RES APCATA 13557 S0926-860X(12)00101-9 10.1016/j.apcata.2012.02.028 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Manufacturing of syngas or hydrogen from coal: (A) classical process path and (B) process path using sulfur-resistant catalysts [9]. Fig. 2 Flow diagram of the reaction system for determination of the catalysts activity: (1) H2S generator, (2) steam generator, (3) reactor with Ni–Mo/Al2O3, (4) mixer, (5) gradientless Zielinski reactor with a sample, (6) dry ice cold trap, (7) gas analyzer, (8) flowmeter, and (9) computer. Fig. 3 Temperature-programmed reduction profiles of standard and potassium promoted Co–Mo catalysts. Tysiąclecia Państwa Polskiego 13A, 24-110 Puławy, Poland b Jagiellonian University, Faculty of Chemistry, Ingardena 3, 30-060 Kraków, Poland c University of Maria Curie-Sklodowska, Faculty of Chemistry, Department of Chemical Technology, Pl. M. Curie-Sklodowskiej 3, 20-031 Lublin, Poland ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +48 81 473 15 23; fax: +48 81 473 15 23. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Flash calcined alumina and alkali promotion of Co–Mo catalysts for sour gas shift. ► Catalysts with two methods of preparation and varying promoter content. ► High activity catalysts by cobalt precursor addition to carrier followed by Mo and K salts incorporation. ► Strong relationship between activity and surface concentration of Co–Mo–S and Mo5+ species. ► Optimal potassium content and preparation method of industrial catalysts. Potassium promoted Co–Mo catalysts supported on flash-calcined alumina for sour WGS process have been prepared. The oxide form of samples has been characterized by ICP-OES method, N2 adsorption, temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) and the sulfides form after the catalytic activity test by means of XPS. Catalytic activity measurements were carried out in gradientless reactor in a kinetic region at low partial pressure of reagents. A strong effect of the promoter addition sequence to the support has been observed. The highest activity in the WGS process was determined for the potassium promoted Co–Mo/Al2O3 catalyst with a K/Mo ratio of 0.06 obtained by a simultaneous impregnation of flash-calcined alumina with aqueous solution of K and Mo salts. Potassium addition significantly changes reducibility and decreases total surface area of catalysts. XPS results show that the catalyst activity is correlated with the surface concentration of Mo5+ and Co–Mo–S species. Potassium addition enhances the formation of such species. The method of potassium incorporation to the catalyst has been suggested and its optimal content has been determined. The catalyst obtained can be implemented in industrial processes of hydrogen and syngas production from feedstocks with high sulfur content. Keywords Water gas shift reaction Sulfur tolerant catalysts Co–Mo catalysts Flash calcined alumina Potassium promoter 1 Introduction Raw synthesis gases (syngases) prepared by coal gasification are valuable intermediates, which, after appropriate processing, can be applied in methanol, dimethyl ether and liquid hydrocarbons syntheses [1–4]. However, coal and its gasification products contain relatively high amounts of sulfur compounds and other substances, which are very strong poisons to typical metallic catalysts (especially based on copper, nickel and iron) used in the syngases processing. The presence of sulfur-rich components rules out the application of standard catalysts used in the conversion of other raw materials containing a lower content of sulfur compounds, e.g. natural gas [3,5,6]. Therefore, new sulfur-resistant catalysts for the conversion of coal gasification products are still developed. The water gas shift reaction (WGS), CO + H 2 O ↔ CO 2 + H 2 , Δ H 298 ° = − 41.09 kJ mol − 1 is one of the processes requires more resistant catalysts [7,8]. In this case, the replacement of standard WGS catalysts (e.g. Fe–Cr–Cu and Cu–Zn–Al) with modern sulfur-resistant ones can result in elimination of an initial desulfurization stage, a decrease of steam requirements and higher degrees of conversion by much lower steam/gas ratios than in the classical solutions. The application of sulfur-resistant catalysts can considerably simplify a technological scheme of coal-based syngas production by the removal of acid gases (H2S and CO2) in one step by means of absorption methods, e.g. Rectisol [9,10]. In Fig. 1 two solutions for syngas or hydrogen manufacturing from coal, where WGS is a key stage, are compared. Path A illustrates the classical two-stage WGS process, whereas path B involves multistage sour gas shift performed on sulfur-resistant catalysts. The most effective catalysts for WGS of sulfur-contaminated feedstocks are molybdenum sulfide catalysts doped with cobalt or nickel, supported on alumina [8,11] or magnesia–alumina [11–13]. The formula of the proposed Mo-containing catalysts is similar to that for the catalysts used in hydrodesulfurization (HDS) processes [14–17] or in mixed alcohol synthesis (MAS) [18,19]. The Co–Mo oxysulfides are considered as an active phase of sour gas shift catalysts. According to Chen et al. [20] the promoting effect of cobalt is attributed to the easier formation of active sulfides in a Mo–O–Al system [20–22]. Moreover, the activity of Co–Mo species can be enhanced by some additives, especially by tungsten, zirconium or alkali metals [8,11,13,23–30]. Kim and Lee [27] showed that the alkali metals efficiency is diversified and increases in the following order: Li>Na>K>Cs. A support type also influences the activity of WGS catalysts [8,11,30–36]. Łaniecki et al. [32,33] showed the essential effect of the nature and surface area of a support on the properties of Co–Mo catalyst and revealed better properties of molybdenum catalysts deposited on TiO2 or TiO2–ZrO2 than on alumina. Lian et al. [34] compared the Co–Mo catalysts supported on Al2O3 and MgO–Al2O3 and demonstrated that the addition of MgO improved the thermal stability of the catalysts. With increasing the Mg/Al ratio the content of the octahedrally coordinated molybdenum phase, which is responsible for the formation of the catalytically active Co–Mo–S phase, also increased. The optimal activity was achieved at the Mg/Al ratio about 0.5. Nagai et al. [30] reported that the deposition of the Co–Mo system on a MoC support can be a way to obtain the highly active catalysts working at low temperatures (even 170°C). However, the industrial applications of such catalysts are strongly limited due to a very complicated preparation method. The preliminary study presented in literature [37] indicated that carbonaceous materials could be also an effective support for the Co–Mo catalysts dedicated to the sour gas shift processes. Nowadays, aluminum oxides varying in chemical and surface properties are most often used as supports of K–Co–Mo catalysts in the industrial practice. As an attractive method of the preparation of alumina support characterized by unique, defined textural and strength properties, flash calcination of gibbsite followed by rehydration of the resulting solid product has been proposed [38]. Flash-calcined alumina seems to be a promising support of Co–Mo catalysts, however, there are no literature data on the efficiency of such catalytic system. In this contribution we present the potassium-promoted Co–Mo catalysts supported on activated alumina prepared by flash calcination. The effect of support and potassium promoter on the catalytic activity of the studied catalysts in the WGS reaction has been investigated. The samples have been characterized by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), low temperature sorption of N2 (BET), temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (sulfide form of the catalysts after the catalytic tests). As a tool for the reliable evaluation of catalytic activity a gradientless Zielinski-type reactor has been used [39]. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis Gibbsite type aluminum hydroxide (technical grade) Alolt 30AF from MAL Magyar Aluminum was flash calcined in a pipe furnace with the efficiency of 10kg/h. The product was dried in air and granulated by pan-granulation with an addition of demineralized water. The granules obtained were hydrated and conditioned in a steam atmosphere at 90–100°C for 24h, followed by drying and calcination at 500°C for 4h [40]. Two series of catalysts with intended contents of Mo and Co equal to 9.0 and 3.0wt.%, respectively, and different sequences of promoter (0.15, 0.25 and 0.40wt.% K) introduction were obtained. In order to prepare the first catalyst series (marked as Co-(K+Mo)/Al2O3) alumina was impregnated (using incipient wetness technique) with an aqueous solution of (NH4)6Mo7O24 and KNO3, dried at 105°C for 12h, calcined at 500°C for 4h and then impregnated with a Co(NO3)3 solution, again dried and calcined under the same conditions. The second catalyst series (marked as (K+Co)-Mo/Al2O3) was synthesized by impregnation of the support with a (NH4)6Mo7O24 aqueous solution, drying at 105°C for 12h, calcination at 500°C for 4h and subsequent impregnation with an aqueous solution of Co(NO3)3 and KNO3 followed by a thermal treatment (the same conditions like in the case of first series). All samples were ground to grain size of 0.10–0.16mm before further studies. 2.2 Characterization Chemical composition of the samples was determined using the emission atomic spectroscopy method with inductively coupled plasma (ICP-OES). The analysis was carried out on a Varian 720-ES ICP-OES spectrometer. Specific surface areas of the catalysts were analyzed by collecting of N2 adsorption isotherms at the temperature of liquid nitrogen (77K) with a SORPTOMATIC apparatus (Fisons, Italy). In the temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) a catalyst sample (ca. 100mg) was treated in a flowing 5% H2/Ar mixture (40mL/min) with temperature increasing rate of 5°C/min up to 800°C. Steam, which was formed as a reduction product, was frozen out on the reactor outlet in a dry ice bath. Changes of H2 concentration in effluent gases were measured by thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) of the sulfidized catalysts were measured on a Prevac photoelectron spectrometer equipped with a hemispherical VG SCIENTA R3000 analyzer. The studied samples were loaded through a load lock (where pressure lower than 3×10−7 mbar was achieved) into an ultrahigh vacuum analytical chamber with the base pressure of 5×10−9 mbar. The XPS measurements were performed with a monochromatized aluminum source AlKα (E =1486.6eV) and a low energy electron flood gun (FS40A-PS) to compensate the charge on the surface of nonconductive samples. Peaks were recorded with constant pass energy of 100eV for the survey and high resolution spectra. Binding energies were referenced to the Al 2p core level (74.6eV) of the Al2O3 support. The composition and chemical surrounding of sample surface were investigated on the basis of the areas and binding energies of Mo 3d, Co 2p, S 2p, K 2p, O 1s, Al 2p, Mg 2p and C 1s photoelectron peaks. Fitting of the high resolution spectra was provided through the CasaXPS software. 2.3 Catalytic test A scheme of laboratory equipment used for studying of sulfidation, catalytic activity and thermal stability is shown in Fig. 2 . The catalyst activity in water gas shift reaction was determined under gradientless conditions in a Zielinski-type reactor [39], in a kinetic regime and at atmospheric pressure. Prior to the activity tests the catalysts (ca. 300mg) were activated in situ via transformation into a sulfide form in a H2S/H2 mixture (containing 2.5vol.% H2S) generated by tiophene hydrogenation on the Ni–Mo/Al2O3 catalyst at 400°C according to the following equation: 2 C 2 H 5 SH + H 2 ↔ C 4 H 10 + 2 H 2 S , Δ H 298 ° = − 270.3 kJ mol − 1 The H2S/H2 mixture was passed through the catalyst sample with the reactor temperature increasing up to 400°C at the rate of 5°C/min. At this temperature sulfidation was carried out over 16h. After the pretreatment the reactor temperature was decreased to 250°C and the reaction was conducted under the following conditions: dry feed gas composition CO/H2S/H2/H2O/N2 =1.60/0.12/20.00/4.5/73.78 (vol.%), temperature range 250–450°C, GHSV=3NLg−1 h−1. Taking into account the results of previous investigations [29] and assuming that the reaction is first order with respect to CO concentration [8,30], we have used a reaction rate r 0.4[L/gcat h] at the same conversion degree of 40% as a measure of the catalysts activity. Thermal stability test was performed for the most active samples. This evaluation was based on a comparison of activity changes before and after overheating at 450°C over 24h in a stream of process gas. The investigation procedure was the following: activity measurement of a fresh sample in the temperature range 250–450°C at the rate of 5°C/min and maintaining at 450°C over 24h, temperature decrease and the repeated activity measurement in the temperature range of 250–450°C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural and redox properties of catalysts The chemical compositions and surface areas (S BET) of the prepared catalysts are listed in Table 1 . All the samples contain 8.9–9.5wt.% Mo and 2.5–3.0wt.% Co. It indicates that the real and nominal (9.0wt.% Mo and 3wt.% Co) chemical composition of the obtained catalysts are in good agreement. The potassium content in both series, which differ with the potassium addition sequence, is in the range of 0.15–0.38wt.% K. The total specific surface area of the flash calcined alumina support is 220.0m2/g and decreases after the introduction of active phase components on the support surface. This effect is strong in the case of the alkali-free Co–Mo catalysts and is further enhanced by the potassium addition. The similar tendency is observed irrespectively of the preparation method and alkali addition sequence. Fig. 3 shows a comparison of reduction profiles recorded for the Co–Mo/Al2O3, Co-(10K+Mo)/Al2O3 and (10K+Co)-Mo/Al2O3 catalysts. The reduction of the Co–Mo/Al2O3 catalyst begins at about 240°C and proceeds by two essential steps observed in the temperature range of 240–380°C and 380–510°C, respectively. The low temperature effect with a relatively low intensity corresponds to the reduction of Mo–O and Co–O species weakly bonded to the alumina support, whereas the medium temperature one can be attributed to the reduction of Mo6+ to Mo4+. The similar results were collected for the Co-(10K+Mo)/Al2O3 and (10K+Co)-Mo/Al2O3 catalysts. The reduction beginning is observed at about 240 and 230°C with the dominant reduction step in the temperature range of 440–590°C and 440–600°C for Co-(10K+Mo)/Al2O3 and (10K+Co)-Mo/Al2O3, respectively. One can notice that potassium doping results in stabilization of Mo and Co oxides, which are reduced a somewhat more difficult than analogous species not promoted with K. The dominant medium temperature peak is shifted towards higher temperatures, from 470 for Co–Mo/Al2O3 to 480 and 490°C for Co-(10K+Mo)/Al2O3 and (10K+Co)-Mo/Al2O3, respectively. Moreover, in the case of the Co-(10K+Mo)/Al2O3 catalyst, the appearance of second medium temperature peak reveals the presence of additional form of reducible oxides. For all the studied samples at temperatures above 600°C a deep reduction of Mo4+ to Mo0 and Co3+ to Co0 occurs [21]. The amounts of hydrogen consumed during the reduction process of the studied samples are compared in Table 2 . Only slight differences in the hydrogen consumption are determined for the catalysts containing a similar content of potassium. Nevertheless, the presented comparison shows that total hydrogen consumption was about 50% lower for the potassium-doped catalysts than for alkali-free one. It can indicate that the potassium addition significantly changes the sample reducibility. It is most likely that doping with potassium results in a transformation of surface [Mo7O24]6− clusters into hardly reducible [MoO4]2− species [16]. 3.2 Catalytic activity in WGS process The effect of temperature, potassium content and the method of its addition on the activity of the Co–Mo/Al2O3 catalysts in the WGS reaction is shown in Fig. 4 . It has been reported by many authors [11] that due to the exothermic nature of the WGS reaction, temperature is a crucial parameter, which may limit the efficiency of the reaction in terms of both CO conversion and H2 production. However, an increase in the catalytic activity is observed with increasing temperature in the studied temperature range. Among the samples doped with potassium the highest reaction rate was measured for the catalyst with K/Mo=0.06. The studied catalysts can be ordered with respect to the activity as follows: (10K+Co)-Mo/Al2O3 >(15K+Co)-Mo/Al2O3 >(5K+Co)-Mo/Al2O3 Co-(10K+Mo)/Al2O3 >Co-(15K+Mo)/Al2O3 >Co-(5K+Mo)/Al2O3. Besides the potassium content also a method used for the alkali promoter doping strongly influences the catalytic activity. The addition of potassium together with ammonium molybdate to the system is more effective. Such catalysts reveal the activity about 20% higher in the temperature range of 250–400°C compared to their analogues obtained by doping of potassium simultaneously with Co(NO3)3. Temperature of the WGS process strongly influences the catalyst stability. The thermal resistance of the WGS catalysts is a crucial parameter indicating its quality and expected life time. The results of thermal stability test for the Co–Mo/Al2O3, Co-(10K+Mo)/Al2O3 and (10K+Co)-Mo/Al2O3 catalysts are presented in Fig. 5 . It was found that the Mo-containing catalysts show relatively high resistance to the thermal treatment. About 30% (for Co-(10K+Mo)/Al2O3 catalyst) and 20% (for Co–Mo/Al2O3 and (10K+Co)-Mo/Al2O3 catalysts) decrease in the activity was observed, that may be caused by intensive recrystallization and “potassium leakage” during the catalyst performance [41,42]. 3.3 Changes of catalyst surface during WGS process The effect of potassium doping on the Co–Mo catalysts was studied by XPS measurements performed for the samples in the sulfide form obtained by the treatment with a H2S/H2 mixture followed by the catalytic run using a model feed containing H2S. The surface composition was measured for the K-free Co–Mo/Al2O3 sample, as well as for Co-(10K+Mo)/Al2O3 and (10K+Co)-Mo/Al2O3 (Table 3 ). The elements detected in all the samples were Mo, Co, Al, S, O and C. The presence of molybdenum in Mo4+, Mo5+ and Mo6+ oxidation states is observed on the surface of all the tested samples after the catalytic test (Table 4 ). Molybdenum species with a binding energy of 228.6–228.8eV can be attributed to Mo4+ formed by reduction of Mo5+ oxysulfide during the reaction of oxygen vacancies with CO [43]. The molybdenum species with binding energy of 229.7–230.0eV are assigned to Mo5+, and a Mo 3d band at 232.3–232.5eV corresponds to Mo6+ in MoO2S2 2− or MoO3S2− and MoOS2 [44]. Deconvolution results (see Table 5 and Fig. 6 ) show that MoS2 is a dominant phase in all the tested samples. Doping with potassium results in changes of the catalyst surface. More active phases appeared: Mo5+ species formed by a substitution of sulfur atom by oxygen one [13] and Co–Mo–S phase produced by sulfurization at a H2/H2S atmosphere. The highest content of Mo5+ species was observed for the Co-(10K+Mo)/Al2O3 catalyst. Co is present on the sample surface as cobalt (II) oxide, Co–Mo–S and Co9S8 at the binding energies of 781.4–781.6, 778.2–778.4 and 779.5–779.9 [44], respectively (Table 4). The deconvolution results (see Table 5 and Fig. 7 ) show that a majority of Co exists as Co9S8 for all the studied samples. In the case of the K-doped catalysts a decrease in an amount of Co2+ in CoAl2O4 spinel and an increase in a content of catalytically active Co–Mo–S phase was found. Different sulfur species such as sulfide (S2−) at 161.4–161.6eV, bridging disulfide (S2 2−) and oxysulfides/polysufides at 162.8–163.1eV [44] are registered. Higher amounts of oxysulfides and polysufides were detected for the samples promoted with K. The amount of sulfur on the catalyst surface inferred from the S/Mo ratio (Table 5), increased from 1.90 (for the (10K+Co)-Mo/Al2O3 sample) to 2.42 (for the Co-(10K+Mo)/Al2O3 sample). For the K-promoted samples the lower binding energies Mo and S than for the catalyst without potassium were observed. Moreover, the K-doted samples showed a higher amount of oxysulfides and polysufides compared to the K-free sample (Fig. 8 ). Fig. 9 shows the correlation between the catalytic activity in the WGS process and the ratio of Mo5+/Al and Co–Mo–S/Al determined by XPS. It seems that Mo5+and Co–Mo–S species could be potentially active sites for the WGS process. The alkali-doped samples, having a higher content of these phases compared to Co-Mo/Al2O3, appeared to be significantly more active catalysts of the WGS process. 4 Conclusions - High specific surface area of flash-calcined alumina exhibits it as a proper support for the Co–Mo catalysts. - The potassium addition to the Co–Mo/Al2O3 catalyst decreases its total surface area, retards the reducibility and shifts the reduction bands towards a bit higher temperatures. - The correlation between the catalytic activity and the surface composition determined by XPS was found. The higher content of Mo5+ and Co–Mo–S species enhances the activity of the studied catalysts. - The highest activity in the WGS process was determined for the potassium promoted Co–Mo/Al2O3 catalyst with a K/Mo ratio of 0.06. Simultaneous impregnation of flash-calcined alumina with aqueous solution of K and Mo salts is an effective way to obtain efficient sour gas shift catalyst. - Above preparation method of sour gas shift catalysts has been suggested which could find an industrial application. coredata.dc:description: Potassium promoted Co–Mo catalysts supported on flash-calcined alumina for sour WGS process have been prepared. The oxide form of samples has been characterized by ICP-OES method, N2 adsorption, temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) and the sulfides form after the catalytic activity test by means of XPS. Catalytic activity measurements were carried out in gradientless reactor in a kinetic region at low partial pressure of reagents. A strong effect of the promoter addition sequence to the support has been observed. The highest activity in the WGS process was determined for the potassium promoted Co–Mo/Al2O3 catalyst with a K/Mo ratio of 0.06 obtained by a simultaneous impregnation of flash-calcined alumina with aqueous solution of K and Mo salts. Potassium addition significantly changes reducibility and decreases total surface area of catalysts. XPS results show that the catalyst activity is correlated with the surface concentration of Mo5+ and Co–Mo–S species. Potassium addition enhances the formation of such species. The method of potassium incorporation to the catalyst has been suggested and its optimal content has been determined. The catalyst obtained can be implemented in industrial processes of hydrogen and syngas production from feedstocks with high sulfur content.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of flash calcined alumina support and potassium doping on the activity of Co–Mo catalysts in sour gas shift process
